On the night of September 2nd, myself and some first aiders were on stand by near the Mong Kok police station. When the police were taking two men into custody at the police station, some police officers suddenly pepper sprayed the journalists and first aiders present at the scene. They then forcefully pushed over a woman and pinned her to the ground, and also pepper sprayed her. That woman expressed her pain and discomfort, and suffered facial injuries. Some of my fellow colleagues rushed over to provide first aid, but an out of control police officer pepper sprayed those first aiders in the face.

At that moment, with the injured woman repeatedly expressing her pain and discomfort, I knelt down to provide first aid for her. She also told me that she has a heart condition. At the same time, a police officer brutally tried to pull us apart, so I held onto the patient tightly and loudly requested that a female police officer be present on the scene, and that the patient has a heart condition. But then the police hit me on my helmet with their baton, and pepper sprayed myself and the patient. When I refused to let go of the patient, they ripped off my helmet and goggles, forcefully pulled my hair, and directly sprayed pepper spray and CS (tear gas) spray into my face.

After this, I continued to try administer first aid to the patient, and when a police officer saw this, he handcuffed my right hand and the patient's hand together with zero warning. We were then surrounded by 5-6 riot police officers. We did not resist in any way, and did not understand the purpose of the behaviour of the police.

Tear gas grenades were then used, but both myself and the patient did not even have a basic face mask on at that point. The patient continued to repeat that she is experiencing a lot of pain in her chest. When my fellow first aiders came to help us, the police also used their batons to hit one of them.

In the end, I could only think that it was fortunate that I managed to block off the pepper spray, CS spray and tear gas with my body, away from the patient, as I cannot imagine what the consequences might be had the patient, who has a heart condition, been exposed to them. It was incredibly painful for me, but if this happens again next time, I will still be there and offer first aid to those who need it.
